pageProps.contentHtml:
measure theory, Stone-Weierstrass

Let J⊆RJ \subseteq \RJ⊆R be a compact interval, and let μ\muμ be a finite Borel measure whose support lies in JJJ. For z∈C∖Jz \in \C \setminus Jz∈C∖J define

Fμ(z)=∫R1z−t dμ(t).F_\mu\p{z} = \int_\R \frac{1}{z - t} \,\diff\mu\p{t}.Fμ​(z)=∫R​z−t1​dμ(t).

Prove that the mapping μ↦Fμ\mu \mapsto F_\muμ↦Fμ​ is one-to-one.
Solution.

Let t0∈R∖Jt_0 \in \R \setminus Jt0​∈R∖J and δ=d(t0,J)>0\delta = d\p{t_0, J} > 0δ=d(t0​,J)>0, since JJJ is compact. Thus, if t∈Jt \in Jt∈J, then

1z−t=1(z−t0)−(t−t0)=−1t−t011−z−t0t−t0=−∑n=0∞1t−t0(z−t0t−t0)n=−∑n=0∞(z−z0)n(t−t0)n+1\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{z - t} &= \frac{1}{\p{z - t_0} - \p{t - t_0}} \\ &= -\frac{1}{t - t_0} \frac{1}{1 - \frac{z - t_0}{t - t_0}} \\ &= -\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{1}{t - t_0} \p{\frac{z - t_0}{t - t_0}}^n \\ &= -\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{\p{z - z_0}^n}{\p{t - t_0}^{n+1}} \end{aligned}z−t1​​=(z−t0​)−(t−t0​)1​=−t−t0​1​1−t−t0​z−t0​​1​=−n=0∑∞​t−t0​1​(t−t0​z−t0​​)n=−n=0∑∞​(t−t0​)n+1(z−z0​)n​​

converges locally uniformly on ∣z−t0∣<δ\abs{z - t_0} < \delta∣z−t0​∣<δ. Hence,

Fμ(z)=−∫R∑n=0∞(z−z0)n(t−t0)n+1 dμ(t)=∑n=0∞(−∫R1(t−t0)n+1 dμ(t))(z−z0)n.\begin{aligned} F_\mu\p{z} &= -\int_\R \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{\p{z - z_0}^n}{\p{t - t_0}^{n+1}} \,\diff\mu\p{t} \\ &= \sum_{n=0}^\infty \p{-\int_\R \frac{1}{\p{t - t_0}^{n+1}} \,\diff\mu\p{t}} \p{z - z_0}^n. \end{aligned}Fμ​(z)​=−∫R​n=0∑∞​(t−t0​)n+1(z−z0​)n​dμ(t)=n=0∑∞​(−∫R​(t−t0​)n+11​dμ(t))(z−z0​)n.​

Hence, if Fμ=FνF_\mu = F_\nuFμ​=Fν​, then by uniqueness of power series, we get

∫R1(t−t0)n+1 dμ(t)=∫R1(t−t0)n+1 dν(t)\int_\R \frac{1}{\p{t - t_0}^{n+1}} \,\diff\mu\p{t} = \int_\R \frac{1}{\p{t - t_0}^{n+1}} \,\diff\nu\p{t}∫R​(t−t0​)n+11​dμ(t)=∫R​(t−t0​)n+11​dν(t)

for all n≥0n \geq 0n≥0. Let

A={∑k=1Nck(t−t0)nk | N∈N, ck∈R, nk∈N}.A = \set{\sum_{k=1}^N \frac{c_k}{\p{t - t_0}^{n_k}} \st N \in \N,\ c_k \in \R,\ n_k \in \N}.A={k=1∑N​(t−t0​)nk​ck​​∣∣​N∈N, ck​∈R, nk​∈N}.

This is a subalgebra which separates points and vanishes nowhere on JJJ, so by Stone-Weierstrass, AAA is dense in C(J)C\p{J}C(J). Hence, μ=ν\mu = \nuμ=ν on a dense subset of C(J)C\p{J}C(J), so they agree on all of C(J)C\p{J}C(J). By Riesz representation, this means μ=ν\mu = \nuμ=ν as measures on JJJ. Since μ\muμ and ν\nuν are supported on JJJ, we see that μ=ν\mu = \nuμ=ν as measures on R\RR, which was what we wanted to show.
